body:
It's hard to detect 100% correctly, so better to ask. CUDA and cuDNN are separate packages and could be in different locations depending on how the user set things up. You can set the CUDA_HOME or CUDNN_HOME environment variables to avoid having to specify these values on the command line.

What specifically is 'not the same as the BUILD.md documentation'?

setup.py is used by build.sh to create the python wheel if '--build_wheel' is specified.
What should I do, if I want build onnxruntime against TensorRT 5.1.5 as backend?
You can use the docker file for a tensorrt build as an example. https://github.com/microsoft/onnxruntime/blob/master/dockerfiles/Dockerfile.tensorrt

@skottmckay  Thank u for this useful docker file.

I am running on local command like this:

```
sudo ./build.sh \
	--use_cuda \
	--cuda_version=10.1 \
	--cuda_home=/usr/local/cuda \
	--cudnn_home=/usr/local/cuda \
	--use_tensorrt --tensorrt_home=$HOME/tensorrt5.1.5 \
	--build_shared_lib --enable_pybind --build_wheel

```

I got some error like:

```
CMake Error at CMakeLists.txt:579 (enable_language):
  No CMAKE_CUDA_COMPILER could be found.

  Tell CMake where to find the compiler by setting either the environment
  variable "CUDACXX" or the CMake cache entry CMAKE_CUDA_COMPILER to the full
  path to the compiler, or to the compiler name if it is in the PATH.

```

It cann't found cuda, for why??
Strange, on my another machine which installed cuda10, these command are work......

I don't know why, it's not work on CUDA10.1:


I'm not sure you've proven an issue with ORT, however it's hard to say without a lot more details about the working and non-working machines that you have. Like linux distribution and version, gcc version, CUDA/CUDNN version, cmake version etc. etc.

In order to determine whether certain things can be enabled or not, it's common for cmake to attempt using a feature and seeing if a test build fails or not. Those errors that you have seen may just mean it will disable a feature, and are not necessarily the root cause of it having issues with your CUDA setup. Most likely a relevant cmake error would involving running or attempting to run nvcc, and not the c++ compiler. 

Another observation is that there are no other reports of issues building with CUDA on linux, and you yourself have a working machine. That seems to make your one machine that doesn't work an outlier, suggesting an issue specific to that machine rather than ORT. 

Could you provide more details about the two machines and try and identify what relevant components differ between the two?

gcc/g++ 5,6 both not work, cmake I tested 3.14, 3.15, my CUDA is 10.1, Ubuntu 16.04. I think the error throws out is not the root reason.....
and I totally have no idea why this error:

```
c++: error: unrecognized command line option '-Wdeprecated-copy'; did you mean '-Wdeprecated'?

```
When I cat the cmake output log

I am not mentioned about ORT issue, but there must be some logic not properly handled in CMakeLists or some where.... Since I post this issue here and I have tested on some normal develop environments I believe this issue will occurred by others as well.

**the question is**:

```
-- The CUDA compiler identification is unknown
CMake Error at CMakeLists.txt:579 (enable_language):
  No CMAKE_CUDA_COMPILER could be found.

  Tell CMake where to find the compiler by setting either the environment
  variable "CUDACXX" or the CMake cache entry CMAKE_CUDA_COMPILER to the full
  path to the compiler, or to the compiler name if it is in the PATH.


-- Configuring incomplete, errors occurred!

```

I always hit this even I set `CUDACXX` :

```
onnxruntime git:(master) $ echo $CUDACXX
/usr/local/cuda/bin/nvcc
```

Pretty sure you can ignore the 'errors' about c++ flags. The issue is it can't find the CUDA compiler leading to this message in the cmake output.

> Compiler: CMAKE_CUDA_COMPILER-NOTFOUND 

If I look at output for a successful setup it doesn't have an error when building CMakeCUDACompilerId.cu.

Given you've provided a path to /user/local/cuda I'm wondering how you set that directory up? Does it have the include and libraries directories? How do the files under that path compare to the setup on the working machine that you have?

You should also be able to try building CMakeCUDACompilerId.cu directly to see what result you get. That file will most likely be under build/Linux/<config>/CMakeFiles/<cmake version>/CompilerIdCuda. 

I would suggest getting the full nvcc command to build CMakeCUDACompilerId.cu from the cmake output from the good machine, and attempting to run it on the bad machine.

My CUDA is ok, and my nvcc can built many other .cu files. I just successfully build pytorch from source. The issue is how onnxruntime called cmake to build with you defined flags.

Could u help build onnxruntime with CUDA10.1, I pretty sure this is happened on CUDA10.1 only since I have no such problem on CUDA10.

I can't reproduce your issue, and given nobody else has reported this problem that I'm aware of, it seems to be specific to the setup you have on your machine. 

Here are the steps I took:

Starting with a clean Azure Data Science VM (https://azure.microsoft.com/en-au/services/virtual-machines/data-science-virtual-machines/) with Ubuntu 16.04 on an NC6 machine (K80 GPU) I did the following:

Update package lists
`username@vmname:~$ sudo apt upgrade`

Installed cmake 3.15 (user level) and updated PATH to use it
```
username@vmname:~$ wget https://github.com/Kitware/CMake/releases/download/v3.15.3/cmake-3.15.3-Linux-x86_64.sh
username@vmname:~$ sh ./cmake-3.15.3-Linux-x86_64.sh
username@vmname:~$ export PATH=~/cmake-3.15.3-Linux-x86_64/bin:$PATH
username@vmname:~$ which cmake
/home/username/cmake-3.15.3-Linux-x86_64/bin/cmake
```

Upgraded CUDA to 10.1 as the default Linux DSVM has 10.0
```
username@vmname:~$ sudo apt install cuda
Reading package lists... Done
Building dependency tree
Reading state information... Done
The following additional packages will be installed:
  cuda-10-1 cuda-command-line-tools-10-1 cuda-compiler-10-1 cuda-cudart-10-1 cuda-cudart-dev-10-1 cuda-cufft-10-1 cuda-cufft-dev-10-1 cuda-cuobjdump-10-1 cuda-cupti-10-1
  cuda-curand-10-1 cuda-curand-dev-10-1 cuda-cusolver-10-1 cuda-cusolver-dev-10-1 cuda-cusparse-10-1 cuda-cusparse-dev-10-1 cuda-demo-suite-10-1 cuda-documentation-10-1
  cuda-driver-dev-10-1 cuda-drivers cuda-gdb-10-1 cuda-gpu-library-advisor-10-1 cuda-libraries-10-1 cuda-libraries-dev-10-1 cuda-license-10-1 cuda-memcheck-10-1
  cuda-misc-headers-10-1 cuda-npp-10-1 cuda-npp-dev-10-1 cuda-nsight-10-1 cuda-nsight-compute-10-1 cuda-nsight-systems-10-1 cuda-nvcc-10-1 cuda-nvdisasm-10-1 cuda-nvgraph-10-1       cuda-nvgraph-dev-10-1 cuda-nvjpeg-10-1 cuda-nvjpeg-dev-10-1 cuda-nvml-dev-10-1 cuda-nvprof-10-1 cuda-nvprune-10-1 cuda-nvrtc-10-1 cuda-nvrtc-dev-10-1 cuda-nvtx-10-1
  cuda-nvvp-10-1 cuda-runtime-10-1 cuda-samples-10-1 cuda-sanitizer-api-10-1 cuda-toolkit-10-1 cuda-tools-10-1 cuda-visual-tools-10-1 libcublas-dev libcublas10 libcuda1-418          nsight-compute-2019.4.0 nsight-systems-2019.3.7 nvidia-418 nvidia-418-dev nvidia-modprobe nvidia-opencl-icd-418 nvidia-settings
The following packages will be REMOVED:
  libcuda1-410 nvidia-410 nvidia-410-dev nvidia-opencl-icd-410
The following NEW packages will be installed:
  cuda cuda-10-1 cuda-command-line-tools-10-1 cuda-compiler-10-1 cuda-cudart-10-1 cuda-cudart-dev-10-1 cuda-cufft-10-1 cuda-cufft-dev-10-1 cuda-cuobjdump-10-1 cuda-cupti-10-1        cuda-curand-10-1 cuda-curand-dev-10-1 cuda-cusolver-10-1 cuda-cusolver-dev-10-1 cuda-cusparse-10-1 cuda-cusparse-dev-10-1 cuda-demo-suite-10-1 cuda-documentation-10-1
  cuda-driver-dev-10-1 cuda-gdb-10-1 cuda-gpu-library-advisor-10-1 cuda-libraries-10-1 cuda-libraries-dev-10-1 cuda-license-10-1 cuda-memcheck-10-1 cuda-misc-headers-10-1
  cuda-npp-10-1 cuda-npp-dev-10-1 cuda-nsight-10-1 cuda-nsight-compute-10-1 cuda-nsight-systems-10-1 cuda-nvcc-10-1 cuda-nvdisasm-10-1 cuda-nvgraph-10-1 cuda-nvgraph-dev-10-1        cuda-nvjpeg-10-1 cuda-nvjpeg-dev-10-1 cuda-nvml-dev-10-1 cuda-nvprof-10-1 cuda-nvprune-10-1 cuda-nvrtc-10-1 cuda-nvrtc-dev-10-1 cuda-nvtx-10-1 cuda-nvvp-10-1 cuda-runtime-10-1     cuda-samples-10-1 cuda-sanitizer-api-10-1 cuda-toolkit-10-1 cuda-tools-10-1 cuda-visual-tools-10-1 libcublas-dev libcublas10 libcuda1-418 nsight-compute-2019.4.0
  nsight-systems-2019.3.7 nvidia-418 nvidia-418-dev nvidia-opencl-icd-418
The following packages will be upgraded:
  cuda-drivers nvidia-modprobe nvidia-settings
3 upgraded, 58 newly installed, 4 to remove and 134 not upgraded.
```

Validated the nvcc version
```
username@vmname:~$ which nvcc                                                                                                                                           /usr/local/cuda/bin/nvcc
username@vmname:~$ nvcc --version 
nvcc: NVIDIA (R) Cuda compiler driver
Copyright (c) 2005-2019 NVIDIA Corporation
Built on Sun_Jul_28_19:07:16_PDT_2019
Cuda compilation tools, release 10.1, V10.1.243
```

Downloaded CUDNN 7.6.3 runtime and development packages and installed them. Copied the necessary files from the install path to the CUDA install
```
username@vmname:~$ sudo apt install ./libcudnn7-dev_7.6.3.30-1+cuda10.1_amd64.deb ./libcudnn7_7.6.3.30-1+cuda10.1_amd64.deb 
username@vmname:$ sudo cp /usr/include/cudnn.h /usr/local/cuda/include/
username@vmname:$ sudo cp /usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libcudnn* /usr/local/cuda/lib64/
```

Set the environment variables to point to that:
```
username@vmname:~$ export CUDA_HOME=/usr/local/cuda
username@vmname:~$ export CUDNN_HOME=/usr/local/cuda
```

Downloaded ORT and built. Build ran without issue.
```
username@vmname:~$ git clone --recursive https://github.com/Microsoft/onnxruntime
username@vmname:~$ cd onnxruntime
username@vmname:~$ ./build.sh --use_cuda
```

No issues with cmake finding CUDA
```
-- The CUDA compiler identification is NVIDIA 10.1.243
-- Check for working CUDA compiler: /usr/local/cuda/bin/nvcc
-- Check for working CUDA compiler: /usr/local/cuda/bin/nvcc -- works
```
thanks for dedicated instructions. I pulled the latest code today and remove my `sudo` command, it build successfully now.

very similar issue here:
https://github.com/microsoft/onnxruntime/issues/3024
